result.title: Overview of alternative CLAIM technologies and marine litter cleanup industry
result.description:
"Overview of alternative CLAIM technologies and marine litter cleanup industry.
The Deliverable was submitted on 31 October 2018 as scheduled and approved during the PR1 review. The initial DoA title was ""Report and Factsheet: Overview of the types of policy instruments relevant to addressing marine litter"". However for reasons explained in the AMD justification letter, a change of the title was deemed necessary as instead of copying this existing work, which would have little incremental value, it was decided to investigate in the first year of the project in WP5 how much data and information could be retrieved about alternative marine litter clean-up technologies that were already available on European markets and elsewhere to conduct an integrated assessment. Such a market assessment and review of existing (competing) marine litter cleanup technologies was considered of very high value to the project consortium, in particular the technology providers."

article.title: Investigaci√≥n en las fronteras del conocimiento para el Pacto Verde: impulsar los objetivos clim√°ticos de Europa mediante la innovaci√≥n y la transformaci√≥n
article.teaser: Con el Pacto Verde Europeo, la Comisi√≥n Europea tiene como objetivo que la Uni√≥n Europea alcance la neutralidad en carbono de aqu√≠ a 2050. Se trata de un objetivo muy ambicioso, y la investigaci√≥n en las fronteras del conocimiento respaldada por el Consejo Europeo de Investigaci√≥n (CEI) desempe√±ar√° un papel fundamental para impulsar la investigaci√≥n y el desarrollo tecnol√≥gico de vanguardia necesarios para hacerlo realidad. En este Results Pack de CORDIS se presentan quince proyectos financiados por el CEI que contribuyen a lograr un futuro ecol√≥gico y sostenible para Europa.

section.sectionBody: El CEI fue fundado en 2007 y su misi√≥n principal es subvencionar a los investigadores europeos m√°s brillantes y perseverantes para realizar estudios en cualquier √°mbito cient√≠fico con la excelencia cient√≠fica como √∫nico criterio de selecci√≥n. Los beneficiarios del CEI suelen a estar a la vanguardia de sus √°mbitos de investigaci√≥n y la financiaci√≥n que se les otorga les brinda la oportunidad de llevar a cabo sus ideas m√°s creativas y, posiblemente, generar resultados que tendr√°n una gran repercusi√≥n en la ciencia, la econom√≠a y la sociedad. Por lo tanto, su investigaci√≥n tiene lugar en las fronteras del conocimiento humano actual y, de hecho, las est√° llevando a√∫n m√°s lejos. En consecuencia, se encuentran en una posici√≥n privilegiada para contribuir al amplio debate actual entorno al Pacto Verde Europeo.

section.sectionTitle: La importancia de la investigaci√≥n en las fronteras del conocimiento
section.sectionBody:
El Pacto Verde en s√≠ abarcar√° casi todos los √°mbitos pol√≠ticos y cient√≠ficos, desde el fomento de la agricultura, la industria y la movilidad sostenibles hasta la energ√≠a renovable, nuevos m√©todos de descontaminaci√≥n e iniciativas para preservar la biodiversidad y favorecer la sostenibilidad urbana. Su objetivo es transformar por completo la econom√≠a y las sociedades europeas para hacerlas verdaderamente ecol√≥gicas.
Dada la enormidad de este cometido, la investigaci√≥n en las fronteras del conocimiento constituir√° un componente esencial de este proceso transformador. Los avances en la comprensi√≥n y el saber humanos impulsados por la investigaci√≥n en las fronteras del conocimiento pueden contribuir a proporcionar un contexto y un aprendizaje relevantes de los problemas en liza y pueden comenzar ya a sentar las bases para el desarrollo de soluciones reales. Un ejemplo actual de esta situaci√≥n es la pandemia de COVID-19, donde casi ciento ochenta proyectos en curso financiados por el CEI tuvieron una repercusi√≥n relevante e inmediata para ayudar a abordarla. Dicha situaci√≥n obedece a que estos proyectos estaban inmersos en una investigaci√≥n que podr√≠a reorientarse f√°cilmente para respaldar el hallazgo de respuestas factibles a las m√∫ltiples adversidades y retos que ha desencadenado el virus.

section.sectionTitle: Los proyectos que allanan el camino
section.sectionBody:
En la misma l√≠nea, muchos de los proyectos financiados por el CEI incluidos en este Results Pack ya est√°n embarcados en una investigaci√≥n pionera que, aunque ahora se encuentre en una fase m√°s te√≥rica o de desarrollo tecnol√≥gico temprano, pronto podr√≠a constituir el eje vertebrador del impulso para lograr los objetivos del Pacto Verde Europeo. Su investigaci√≥n es muy variada y abarca muchos √°mbitos diferentes, pero todos tienen un papel fundamental que desempe√±ar.
Por ejemplo, el proyecto https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/423103/es (ALLEGRO) ha proporcionado informaci√≥n relevante sobre la conducta vial de los peatones y ciclistas que puede ayudar a los centros urbanos congestionados a poner en pr√°ctica mejores sistemas de movilidad sostenible, mientras que el proyecto https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/423104/es (BacBio) espera marcar el camino hacia una agricultura m√°s sostenible, que se base m√°s en microbios beneficiosos y menos en plaguicidas y fungicidas.
Con una visi√≥n m√°s centrada en el sector industrial, el proyecto https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/423105/es (COFLeaF) se ha inspirado en las plantas para desarrollar alternativas ecol√≥gicas a los combustibles qu√≠micos, mientras que el proyecto https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/423106/es (CUSTOM-SENSE) ha desarrollado biosensores que facilitar√°n la identificaci√≥n de microorganismos, que alg√∫n d√≠a podr√≠an ayudar a reemplazar los combustibles f√≥siles como fuentes de compuestos industriales.
En cuanto al sector energ√©tico, el proyecto https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/423109/es (SEEWHI) ha trabajado para optimizar las pr√≥ximas celdas fotovoltaicas de tercera generaci√≥n que auguran una variaci√≥n de la escala industrial barata y r√°pida. Adem√°s, el equipo del proyecto https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/423115/es (WINDMIL) ha creado un nuevo sistema de supervisi√≥n que emplea sensores baratos para inspeccionar y controlar de manera eficiente la estructura y el rendimiento de las turbinas e√≥licas, lo cual podr√≠a resultar en una mayor vida √∫til para esta importante fuente de energ√≠a renovable.
Teniendo en cuenta la biodiversidad y la conservaci√≥n, el proyecto https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/423114/es (TREECLIMBERS) ha estado estudiando las lianas, lo que ha proporcionado informaci√≥n interesante sobre c√≥mo se est√°n adaptando los bosques tropicales al cambio clim√°tico. Mientras que el proyecto https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/423102/es (AIRSCAN) ha presentado una aeronave ultraligera de bajo coste que permite llevar a cabo un mejor seguimiento de los animales sin necesidad de realizar operaciones en tierra.
Finalmente, desde una perspectiva pol√≠tica, el proyecto https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/423113/es (SUSTAINABLEOCEAN) ha ayudado a desarrollar nuevos instrumentos jur√≠dicos para ayudar a los responsables pol√≠ticos a equilibrar los intereses contrapuestos en el mar y crear una pol√≠tica mar√≠tima y una econom√≠a azul m√°s sostenibles. Por otra parte, el proyecto https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/423108/es (LITTLE TOOLS) ha realizado encuestas y an√°lisis pormenorizados para ayudar a explicar c√≥mo se pueden lograr grandes transiciones en la sociedad, en concreto al examinar el crecimiento de la bioeconom√≠a.
Estos ejemplos ofrecen una panor√°mica del men√∫ completo de quince proyectos que se presentan en este Results Pack. Con todo, estos quince proyectos solo son una muestra de c√≥mo la innovaci√≥n y la excelencia impulsadas por la investigaci√≥n en las fronteras del conocimiento ayudar√°n a convertir el objetivo so√±ado del Pacto Verde Europeo en una realidad tangible.

article.title: Innovaciones en la econom√≠a circular aplicadas a la gesti√≥n de los residuos industriales y urbanos

article.title: Improving the processing industry‚Äôs resource efficiency
article.teaser: Innovative new optimisation-based tools aim to make European process industries more energy-efficient and cost-effective.

section.sectionBody:
From food processing to paper production and refineries, industrial processes use a lot of energy. In fact, it is estimated that the industrial sector https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/ieo/pdf/industrial.pdf (uses more delivered energy than any other end-use sector), consuming over half of the world‚Äôs total delivered energy.
But this use of fossil-based energy comes with both a significant price tag and significant carbon emissions. This cost and increasing pressure to cut emissions are pushing the industrial sector to seek new ways to become more resource-efficient ‚Äì which is where the EU-funded https://www.spire2030.eu/copro (CoPro project) comes in.
‚ÄúOur goal was to help reduce the carbon footprint of European process industries by improving the energy and resource efficiency of industrial plants and industrial parks,‚Äù says Sebastian Engell, a professor at https://www.tu-dortmund.de/en/ (TU Dortmund) and CoPro project coordinator.
‚ÄúTo do this, we focused on improving process monitoring and implementing optimal dynamic planning, scheduling and control of interconnected process units and plants.‚Äù

During their work on previous projects, CoPro researchers found that the energy and resource efficiency of processing plants is largely dependent on the coordination of several units, from material handling and storage to the distribution of energy.
‚ÄúMoreover, decisions like what equipment to use when, which load, when it should be maintained, and when to shut it down all have a substantial impact on the plant‚Äôs overall energy use,‚Äù explains Engell.
According to Engell, CoPro aimed to support such decisions using mathematical optimisation. ‚ÄúWe even developed methods to coordinate the operation of processing plants that are connected by resource networks but are operated by different business units of companies,‚Äù he adds.
The project developed nearly 20 different optimisation-based tools. ‚ÄúThese innovations cover a wide range of sectors and they all share the same goal of making European process industries more energy-efficient and cost-effective,‚Äù remarks Engell.
For example, the project developed methods for simplifying the process of implementing advanced digital solutions and integrating model-based solutions into a plant‚Äôs existing information and operational technology.
Other tools helped operators improve energy and material efficiency in petrochemical plants or optimise the use of sterilisers in the production of canned fish. Other methods were designed to anticipate and prevent anomalies in chemical plants.
The CoPro solutions were demonstrated at several industrial plants covering a variety of sectors. These included integrated petrochemical production at http://www.ineoskoeln.de/ (INEOS) (website in German), base chemicals and polymer production at https://www.covestro.com/ (Covestro), cellulose production at https://www.lenzing.com/ (Lenzing AG), consumer product formulation and packaging at https://nl-be.pg.com/ (Procter and Gamble) (website in Flemish), and packing and sterilising fish at https://www.frinsa.es/ (FRINSA) (website in Spanish). Following these demonstrations, several of the plants opted to permanently implement the solutions into their daily operations.

CoPro successfully demonstrated how using optimisation-based solutions can provide significant benefits in industrial applications, contributing to both improved energy efficiency and reduced production costs. According to Engell, if these solutions are rolled out across European process industries, they could reduce on-site material handling time, resource consumption, energy use and greenhouse gas emissions by at least 5 %.
‚ÄúThe CoPro technologies will significantly strengthen the global position of the European process industry and have a positive impact on their carbon emissions and resource efficiency,‚Äù concludes Engell.
The project‚Äôs partners are now working to further develop and deploy advanced solutions, including coordination of coupled plants between different business units or even companies.

article.keywords: CoPro, processing industry, process industries, energy efficiency, industrial, energy, carbon emissions, industrial plants, industrial parks, greenhouse gas

article.title: Intelligent system and equipment for a more agile manufacturing sector in Europe
article.teaser: The European manufacturing industry must become more agile to compete globally, but while automated systems can achieve high productivity and quality, their sensitivity to change is becoming a major roadblock. An EU initiative has introduced a platform to ease the transformation to demanding agile solutions.

section.sectionBody:
‚ÄúOriginal equipment manufacturers (OEMs) need to be able to produce premium quality on demand,‚Äù says Raquel Caldeira, coordinator of the EU-funded https://www.openmos.eu/ (openMOS) project. ‚ÄúTraditional manufacturing models based on large production volumes and continuous improvement are becoming more difficult to sustain.‚Äù Ever-smaller lot sizes are required to achieve short lead times for a growing range of products and variants.
High variety and flexibility is usually the domain of manual manufacturing systems. On the other hand, repeatable high quality is the strength of automation systems. ‚ÄúThe root cause of many warranty issues for high-quality products can be traced back to manual work,‚Äù she notes. Plug-and-produce (P&P) automation systems combined with industrially relevant technology platforms are seen as a solution to address these issues.
Operating system for agile manufacturing production
The openMOS team developed a common, open-source P&P system enabling all stakeholders in the automation system value chain to come together and jointly develop and exploit solutions. It allows quick and efficient integration of machines and automation systems within production environments. This is a prerequisite for implementing Industry 4.0 solutions.
The manufacturing operating system is easily extendible and adaptable to run higher-level control, planning and optimisation functions. Such functions will ease the introduction of new products, work orders and equipment changes, and will facilitate the seamless deployment of optimisation and changeover management strategies.
Introducing new P&P system concepts in manufacturing
Project partners developed several other key innovations, most notably new embedded automation devices and components with P&P capabilities, such as a linear axis system, a rotary module and a click-clack gripper. They delivered a manufacturing service bus ‚Äì an open service-based communication platform used for vertical and horizontal connectivity between P&P automation components and higher-level control and business functions. It guarantees that production is executed continuously in a demand-driven manner.
‚ÄúopenMOS enabled us to test and validate the seamless integration of different standards in the same ecosystem,‚Äù notes Caldeira. She calls this effort ‚Äúa great breakthrough for the adoption of common and open standards in the manufacturing industry to further reuse technology, make processes more flexible and reduce customisation costs.‚Äù
OEMs and system integrators stand to benefit most from the innovations. A reference architecture for P&P assembly systems shows how P&P for manufacturing system concepts can be realised. ‚ÄúThe advantages of agility and resilience are now available without compromising performance,‚Äù adds Caldeira. More flexible processes are available with a clear distinction between production optimisation and time-critical production execution.
These end users now have access to a set of self-deploying, flexible and self-adapting P&P devices. Combined with a device adapter, the devices can extend to existing equipment, such as industrial robots, quality inspection systems and power meters. They don‚Äôt have to deploy every module of the whole developed software stack, just the functionality needed for a particular system. This increases industrial adoption of project results. The system‚Äôs agent cloud and intuitive human-machine interface provide system optimisation recommendations for both cycle time and energy consumption, and ramp-up decision support.
‚ÄúThe openMOS suite of technological tools will help companies manufacture faster, at a consistently higher quality and lower cost, all in an agile environment,‚Äù concludes Caldeira.
